Comment: I agree with all your points.  I hadn't heard of the Haze Report before and I wondered about those figures.  I didn't read the Haze Report, but I did download and skim the same group's 2015 CHAOS Report (PDF: [https://wiki.sj.ifsc.edu.br/images/3/3b/CHAOSReport2015\_rev.pdf](https://wiki.sj.ifsc.edu.br/images/3/3b/CHAOSReport2015_rev.pdf) ) - it's only 11 pages long.  The report covers both public- and private-sector projects and, as I suspected, the government figures are comparable to industry figures.  For example, the "successful" rates range from 21% for government projects to 35% for banking projects.  The government's successful/challenged/failed rates (21%/55%/24%) are on par with telecom industry projects' rates (24%/53%/23%).  Also, big, complex projects (e.g., > $6 million) have a much lower success rate than smaller projects (e.g., < $1 million), regardless of them being government or non-government projects.  Of course, it should be kept in mind that (i) government projects themselves run the gamut of the private industry types (e.g., banking, healthcare, etc.) and (ii) a lot of the government software is developed by contractors.  Thanks for bringing the Standish Group to my (and others!) attention - it's interesting reading.  Like you, I have zero confidence in the Trump admin's efforts and I fear they will make things much, much worse.
